Re ''Why the Best Don't Teach,'' by Harold O. Levy (Op-Ed, Sept. 9):

I agree with Mr. Levy that the bureaucratic hurdles for new teachers must be lessened, and I also agree that salaries and working conditions must be commensurate with other professions'. But let me add another way that the quality of the teaching force can be improved.
Along with 30 other colleagues, I retired from teaching at a large public high school in June. We retired after years of success in the classroom and years of professional accomplishments.

We were not encouraged to stay to mentor our younger colleagues but were offered monetary incentives to leave. That decision was a mistake, because it is possible to train teachers on the job, or at least through an intensive but minimal summer program.
